title: Grade 1 Activities
description: First steps in counting, adding, and patterns

level1.title: Numbers to 120 & Place Value
level1.goal: Understand numbers to 120, recognize place value, and compare two-digit numbers.

g1-l1-big-idea.title: Big idea
g1-l1-big-idea.content: Numbers tell "how many," and they also have structure. In Grade 1, kids learn that **two-digit numbers are tens and ones** (like 47 = 4 tens and 7 ones). This makes counting to 120, comparing, and finding patterns much easier.

g1-l1-notice.title: What to notice
g1-l1-notice.content:
* Counts forward from any number (not only from 1).
* Can say a number as "__ tens and __ ones."
* Compares using tens first (82 > 79 because 8 tens > 7 tens).
* Skip-counts by 10s and notices the pattern (10, 20, 30â€¦).
* Spots patterns on a 120 chart (same ones digit down a column).

g1-l1-home.title: Try at home
g1-l1-home.content:
* **Game A (objects, core idea): "Tens Bundles"**
  Grab 30â€“60 small items (beans/coins/straws). Make bundles of 10 (cups or rubber bands). Ask:
  "How many **tens**? How many **ones**? What number is that?"
* **Game B (second representation): "Hop +10 / +1"**
  Draw a number line 0â€“120. Pick a start (like 34). Take turns calling "+10" or "+1" and hopping a token. Ask: "Where did we land? What changed?"

g1-l1-videos.title: Optional videos
g1-l1-videos.content: **Search YouTube for:** * tens and ones base ten blocks for kids * 120 chart patterns for kids * counting to 120 starting from any number * greater than less than for kids

level2.title: Addition Within 20
level2.goal: Develop fluency with addition facts to 20 using multiple strategies.

g1-l2-big-idea.title: Big idea
g1-l2-big-idea.content: Addition means "put together" or "how many in all." The goal isn't just answersâ€”it's building a few friendly strategies (count on, make ten, doubles) so sums to 20 feel natural.

g1-l2-notice.title: What to notice
g1-l2-notice.content:
* Starts counting from the bigger number (counts on).
* Uses **make ten** (8 + 5 â†’ 10 + 3).
* Recognizes doubles quickly (6 + 6, 7 + 7).
* Can show thinking with objects, a quick drawing, or a number line.
* Story problems: can explain what "in all / altogether" means.

g1-l2-home.title: Try at home
g1-l2-home.content:
* **Game A (core idea): "Make 10 First"**
  Draw a 10-frame (2 rows of 5). Show 7 dots, then add 5 dots. Ask:
  "How many to fill to 10? How many left over? So 7 + 5 = 10 + __."
* **Game B (second representation): "Number Line Jumps"**
  Draw 0â€“20. For 8 + 6: start at 8, jump +6. Then try two jumps (+2, +4) and notice it's the same total.

g1-l2-videos.title: Optional videos
g1-l2-videos.content: **Search YouTube for:** * make ten strategy for kids * number line addition grade 1 * doubles facts addition for kids * addition within 20 strategies for kids

level3.title: Subtraction Within 20
level3.goal: Develop fluency with subtraction facts to 20 and understand the relationship between addition and subtraction.

g1-l3-big-idea.title: Big idea
g1-l3-big-idea.content: Subtraction can mean "take away" **or** "find the difference." It also connects to addition: if 8 + 5 = 13, then 13 âˆ’ 8 = 5. These connections build confidence and number sense.

g1-l3-notice.title: What to notice
g1-l3-notice.content:
* Can act it out with objects (start, take away, what's left).
* Can hop back on a number line.
* Understands "how many more?" as a comparison/difference.
* Uses addition to check subtraction (answer + part = whole).
* Gets comfortable with "missing part" problems (5 + __ = 8).

g1-l3-home.title: Try at home
g1-l3-home.content:
* **Game A (core idea): "Take Away Snack"**
  Put 12 snacks on a plate. Take away 4. Ask "How many left?" Swap roles.
* **Game B (second representation): "Compare in Pairs"**
  Make two piles (9 vs 6). Line them up in pairs. Count the leftovers. Say:
  "9 is __ more than 6."

g1-l3-videos.title: Optional videos
g1-l3-videos.content: **Search YouTube for:** * subtraction within 20 using a number line * fact families addition and subtraction for kids * how many more subtraction for kids * think addition to solve subtraction for kids

level4.title: Word Problems & Equal Sign
level4.goal: Solve word problems involving addition and subtraction, and understand the meaning of the equal sign.

g1-l4-big-idea.title: Big idea
g1-l4-big-idea.content: Word problems bring math to life. The equal sign means **"the same as,"** not "the answer comes next." Kids learn to represent stories with drawings and equations, sometimes with a mystery number.

g1-l4-notice.title: What to notice
g1-l4-notice.content:
* Retells the story: what happened first, what changed, what's asked.
* Draws a simple picture before calculating (circles/boxes/tallies).
* Understands equations like â–¡ + 3 = 9 or 10 = 6 + 4.
* Chooses + or âˆ’ based on the situation (not just keyword hunting).

g1-l4-home.title: Try at home
g1-l4-home.content:
* **Game A (core idea): "Draw the Story"**
  Say: "I had 6 stickers. I got 3 more."
  Child draws 6 circles, then 3 circles, then writes: `6 + 3 = __`.
* **Game B (second representation / everyday): "Equation Balance"**
  Put 5 coins total, show 2 coins, hide the rest under a cup:
  "2 + â–¡ = 5. How many are hiding?"

g1-l4-videos.title: Optional videos
g1-l4-videos.content: **Search YouTube for:** * equal sign means the same as for kids * grade 1 word problems draw a picture * missing number equations for kids * more and fewer comparison word problems for kids

level5.title: Measurement, Time & Shapes
level5.goal: Measure length, tell time, read data, and identify shapes and their attributes.

g1-l5-big-idea.title: Big idea
g1-l5-big-idea.content: This level is "math you can touch." Kids compare and measure length, tell time, read simple graphs, and describe shapes. These skills grow best through small daily practice in real life.

g1-l5-notice.title: What to notice
g1-l5-notice.content:
* Measures by lining up ends and counting units with **no gaps/overlaps**.
* For time, checks the hour hand first, then the minute hand.
* Reads graphs: can answer "most/least/how many more."
* Names shapes and describes sides/corners.
* For halves/fourths, checks that parts are truly equal.

g1-l5-home.title: Try at home
g1-l5-home.content:
* **Game A (core idea): "Measure With Paper Clips"**
  Measure 2â€“3 objects (pencil, spoon, book) using paper clips. Ask:
  "How many clips long? Which is longer?"
* **Game B (everyday-life): "Clock Check"**
  Twice today, ask: "What time is it?"
  First: hour only. Second: hour + half hour if applicable. Bonus: "What will the hour be in 1 hour?"

g1-l5-videos.title: Optional videos
g1-l5-videos.content: **Search YouTube for:** * measuring with nonstandard units for kids * telling time to the hour and half hour for kids * how to read a bar graph for kids * 2d shapes sides and corners for kids * halves and fourths equal shares for kids
